title: What Does “Type Shi” Mean? Plus, Where It Came From & How to Respond

steps.title: “Type shi” refers to something cool, impressive, or high quality.
steps.content: “Type shi” refers to something cool, impressive, or high quality. Whether it’s clothes, music, jewelry, or a luxury lifestyle, “type shi” can be used to talk about anything that’s desirable. “That’s the type shi we need for the project.” “I want the Dubai chocolate type shi for dessert.” “I need that Kylie Jenner, Hamptoms type shi for my party.”

steps.title: “Type shi” is used to express agreement with someone.
steps.content: “Type shi” is used to express agreement with someone. Used over text and in person, “type shi” is another way of saying “I feel you” or “I hear you.” It validates someone’s statement, and indicates you share the same feelings, beliefs, or opinions as them. [1] X Research source Them: “Last night was a movie.” You: “Type shi!” Them: “I don’t want to go to the gym 😩” You: “Type shi…” Them: “Shake Shack is better than In-N-Out.” You: “Type shi.”

steps.title: Alternatively, “type shi” can mean anything and apply to any situation.
steps.content: Alternatively, “type shi” can mean anything and apply to any situation. According to this viral video by TikToker @imisraell, “type shi” can be used to show someone you’re listening, when somebody’s lying, or whenever you don’t know the exact thing someone’s referring to. It can mean “yeah,” “no,” “maybe,” “relatable,” or anything else you want it to mean. So, use body language (or emojis) when delivering your message to clarify what you’re saying. [2] X Research source Them: “You don’t wanna work today?” You: “Type shi 😔” Them: “You really don’t care, do you?” You: “Type shi 🙄” Them: “I need 5-7 business days to recover from the party.” You: “Type shi (nod in agreement).”

steps.title: “Type shi” stems from African American Vernacular English (AAVE).
steps.content: “Type shi” stems from African American Vernacular English (AAVE). While the exact origin of “type shi” is unknown, the phrase became popular in the early 2000s, mainly due to its use in rap and hip-hop songs. “Type” is another way of saying “kind of” or “like that” in AAVE, while “shi” is slang for “s***.” From the mid to late 2000s, Gen Zers started using “type shi” on social media (especially TikTok), which further solidified the phrase in casual speech. Famous YouTuber and Twitch Streamer Duke Dennis is known for saying “type s***” a lot. “Type S***” is a popular trap song by Future, Metro Boomin, Travis Scott, and Playboi Carti, with over 120,000 TikTok videos using the audio.

steps.title: Reply with an emoji or Tapback to confirm you heard them.
steps.content: Reply with an emoji or Tapback to confirm you heard them. When you’re struggling to come up with a response, a heart or thumbs up is a great way to let the other person know you got their message. To send a Tapback, tap and hold onto their message, and click on the heart or thumbs up button in the row of reactions. You: “I can pick you up at 8.” Them: “Type shi.” You: “👍” You: “Thanks for being a real friend.” Them: “Type shi.” You: “❤️” You: “The cookies you brought were delicious.” Them: “Type shi.” You: “🤤”

steps.title: Ask a question or switch topics to keep the conversation going.
steps.content: Ask a question or switch topics to keep the conversation going. Don’t want a text conversation to end? Ask the other person a follow up question to what they said or move on to a new topic. If you feel awkward switching subjects, preface your response with “random question…” or “switching gears...” You: “I’m going to go for a jog.” Them: “Type shi.” You: “Wanna join?” You: “I think it’s going to snow tomorrow.” Them: “Type shi.” You: “Do you have a long puffer?” You: “The DJ set was so good.” Them: “Type shi.” You: “Random question, but do you have a turntable?”

steps.title: Word
steps.content: Word Used in person and over text, “word” is another way to say, “okay” or “cool.” It communicates that you heard the other person and agree with what they’re saying. [3] X Research source Them: “FYI, the party is at 10 PM.” You: “Word.” Them: “The WiFi password is 30431294.” You: “Word. Thanks!”

steps.title: Facts
steps.content: Facts “Facts” is another way of saying “agreed.” People typically use it to express agreement with someone, especially if they share a hot take or unpopular opinion. [4] X Research source Them: “Controversial, but Christmas is the worst holiday.” You: “Facts!” Them: “TBH, Friends is not funny at all.” You: “FACTS. It would be dead without the laughing track in the back!”

steps.title: Gang gang
steps.content: Gang gang “Gang gang” is most often used to express agreement with someone. People use it to validate another person’s feelings, beliefs, or opinions, sort of like saying “I’m with you.” [5] X Research source You: “I’m so ready for summer break!” Them: “Gang gang!” You: “Anyone else tired AF?” Them: “Gang gang. I just wanna go home 🥱”

steps.title: Drip
steps.content: Drip “Drip” means someone’s style is cool and fashionable. It’s typically used to describe clothes, shoes, and jewelry, but it can also refer to the way someone carries themself. If you see someone in a stylish outfit, you could compliment them by saying they have “drip.” [6] X Research source “Okay…I see you with the drip!” “Looking fresh in the Off White drip, Josh!” “Did you see that guy’s chain? Bro had some serious drip.”
